I use very often multiple assertXXX in my test cases.  A test case
usually has on purpose but during the steps to the check for the main
purpose, I do a lot of other checks, for example make sure something is
not null, or as in Cedric's example, a connection is established.
Especially since JUnit 3.8 has not dependencies or guarantees a specific
order of executions, those checks are necessary and crucial.

 

Andreas

Is there any situation in which multiple assertions per test can be 
justified? For example, talking to an expensive external resource that 
can't easily be mocked (e.g. third party hardware)?

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chaudhary, Harsh wrote:
> 
>> Is there a way in jUnit to override the failfast behavior e.g. my
code
>> looks like:
>>
>> public void testOrder() {
>>
>> assertEquals(9, Largest.largest(new int[] {9,8,7}));
>>
>> assertEquals(44, Largest.largest(new int[] {8,9,7}));
>>
>> assertEquals(32, Largest.largest(new int[] {7,8,9}));
>>
>> }
>>
>> I know the 2nd and 3rd asserts would fail. I want to see both results
as
>> having failed in my results. But jUnit just stops at the first
failure.
>>
>> Is there any way to change this behavior?
> 
> This is a FAQ. Google "JUnit multiple assertions per test". I explain 
> the reasons why JUnit isn't built this way in _JUnit Recipes_ and a 
> number of us have re-written that answer dozens of times in this
mailing 
> list, so check the archives.
> 
> The short version: No, you can't, and you shouldn't, because those are
3 
> different tests.
> 
> For the longer version, search the web.
> 
> Take care.
